First time in Portugal. We have been shooting for almost a month now, and when Ilene told me you were here, I said ‘let’s go’. I'ma big fan, you know.
I’m a fan of Ilene’s. She’s been a good friend.
We met on another film we did together. The Void. I was the Principal DP on that. We’ve been hanging out, you know.
I’m not sure what that means.
I love Ilene.
Ah. That’s something.
Frankie, Ilene says. May I call you Frankie?
That’s what my friends call me.
You look even better in person, you know. Do people tell you that?
You're being kind.  61.
No, it’s true. You know, I wanted to talk with you about something, if we can find the right time. I have a film project that I want to direct.
Your first time directing?

Yes, well, no. But my first feature. I’ve been thinking about it for a long time. And I’ve shot over 18 films for other people. I’m ready to start, you know. And I think you and I share a taste ina certain kind of cinema. It’s about an opera singer who loses her voice.
Ha. That’s funny.
I think you’d be perfect for it.
I can’t sing.
But that’s it! She loses her voice. It’s almost like silent film acting, and I can’t think of anyone more expressive for the role. Like Greta Garbo.
Or Fatty Arbuckle. Gary laughs, uncomfortably.
Can I can send you the script?
If you’d like. When are you thinking of shooting this?
It’s not going to happen now. I need a year, at least, to prepare. (MORE )

If we’re going to collaborate I think it’s better to be up front with you, it’s going to take time to get it together. You know the business. I’d say realistically it will be a year, a year and a half, before we start shooting.
I see. Frankie takes a deep breath. They walk side by side in silence for a moment.

You know, Frankie. I’m going to take time off to work on this film. I have a house in Water Mill, that’s just under two hours from New York, it’s a beautiful place. I've invited Ilene to come live with me. Don’t you think it would be a good idea for her to settle down a little bit? Not travel so much. Not work so much on projects she doesn’t really care about?
Does it matter what I think?
You know her well.

But does it matter? If you’ve invited her, then you should know. Ilene is the kind of woman who'll tell you straight to your face what she thinks. No bullshit, Ilene. And no bullshitters. She doesn’t have time for people who aren’t very real, very sincere, you know? That's why I like her. Gary doesn’t know quite how to respond.

Now if you’1ll excuse me, I’m going to go look for my son. I haven’t seen him since the morning, and this was meant to be a family vacation.  29 63. She walks away, leaving Gary alone among the trees and th silence.

The cliffs at the end of the beach. Maya, wearing only a T-shirt over her wet beach clothes, hikes/climbs the tric part of a ledge. She places one foot on a rock, while one hand tries to hold on to a higher mark on the ledge. She makes sure the one foot is firm on the rock, while lookin for a safe step for the other foot. She climbs up for a second, but not sure of her next step, strides back down. That’s when a helping hand enters frame. Pedro extends his arm and pulls Maya up. As she climbs, s steps with the wrong foot, and falls into his arms, clums They smile, a bit disconcerted. Maya and Pedro walk hand in hand on this rocky path high at the end of the beach. They are away but not far from t sand, surrounded by the ocean. They stop to look at the v the long golden sand beach, and on the other end, a rocky cliff crowned with small, charming white houses, typical Portuguese.
Is that still Sintra?
That’s Colares, actually.
It’s so pretty.

I knew you would like it. If you like, I can buy you a postcard. Maya faces the view, breathing in the moment. Pedro comes from behind, and puts his arms around her. She holds his arms, welcoming the gesture.
I used to come here with my parents and my sister every summer. My whole life, until I was thirteen.
And then what happened.  64.

My parents got divorced. My vacations were divided between time with Mom, then time with Dad, and there was no time left for this Apple Beach anymore. A SEAGULL flies overhead, and dives into the water. A wav crashes in the ocean down below.

But then I met Bento in Lisboa last year. We played football against each other in a national tournament. His school won, but we became friends after, and he invited me to visit him in Sintra. Pedro turns Maya around. They’re face to face, and she gi him a kiss. Pedro smiles, happily surprised, and soon aft they kiss again, this time a long, slow one, both discove the pleasure of each other’s mouths.
I have a confession. The real story of this Apple Beach has nothing to do with Adam and Eve. I’m sorry. Can I tell you?
It’s okay. If you'd like.

They say that the Ribeira River, over there, used to carry down apples from the farms in Colares all the way to the coast, and they would end on the beach down here. But the thing is, I’ve never seen one single apple tree in Colares, so I don’t believe this story. There aren't any apple farms in Colares. For Maya, he talks too much. She kisses him again. After another long moment, he pulls away, and looks at he with near wonder.
When can I see you again?  30
(laughing) But I’m still here.
I know, but I miss you already. She smiles, happy.
30 Paul is walking alone on the road, appreciating the view enjoying a peaceful moment. He carries the beaten down bouquet of flowers.
Paul! He turns around, and sees his mother rushing down to be w him.
Paul. Attends. J’arrive.
Paul. Wait. I'm coming. He opens his arm, and embraces his mother when she comes close. They hold each other for a long moment, strongly. conversation between them is all in French.
Tiens, c’est pour toi. Elles sont un peu défraichies, mais bon. He hands her the flowers.
Ca tombe bien, moi aussi.
Allez, ga mérite quand méme un selfie. He pulls out his phone.
Ah non, tu as vu ma téte?
These are for you. They've seen better days, I know.
That's perfect, so have I.
Let's take a picture.
Oh no, not with this hair.
Arréte. Tu es super belle aujourd'hui.
Tu dis ga pour me faire plaisir.
Non, c’est la vérité. Tu es magnifique. Tiens, tourne-toi par 1a, avec le paysage derriére nous. 66.
C'mon. You look so beautiful today.
You're just saying that.

But you do. You look wonderful. Come here, turn this way. With the view behind us. Accepting the compliment, Frankie combs her hair with her hands quickly, before positioning herself for a photo. Pa puts his arm around her, and takes a selfie.
On en prend un autre.
One more. She changes her angle slightly. Another click.
Envoie-le a Jimmy.
A vos ordres. They start walking, side by side.
Je n’ai pas trés bien dormi.
Encore te migraines?
Atroces. C’est de pire en pire.
Prends te cachets.
Mais je le prends.
Send it to Jimmy.
Right now.
I didn't sleep very well.
Headaches again?
Awful. They're getting worse.
Take the pills.
I am.
Augment la dose.
Ce n’est pas comme ga que ¢a marche. Il faut que j’en parle au Dr. Bernhard. Tu sais, ils sont déja trés forts.
Et alors? A ce stade... 67.
Take more.
It's not like that. I have to talk to Dr. Bernhard. They're very strong, you know.
So what? At this point. Paul talked without thinking, and his comment hits Franki the wrong way. Her eyes tear up, and she looks away, tryi to hide them from her son. But he knows.
Excuse-moi Maman. vraiment désolé. Je suis
Mais il n’y a pas de quoi.
C’est juste que je ne veux pas que tu souffres.
Tu as raison. A ce stade, qu’est-ce que ga peut faire?
En tout cas, tu as l’air reposée.
Je suis payée pour faire semblant. Frankie takes her bracelet off. before she offers it to him.
Tiens. Je voudrais te le donner.
I'm sorry, Maman. I'm so sorry.
Nothing to be sorry about.
I just don't want you to feel any pain.
You're right. At this point, who cares?
Anyway, you do look rested.
I'm good at pretending. Paul notices her admiring it,
Here. I want you to have this. She pushes the shiny bracelet into his hands.
Je n’en veux pas. He tries to give it back.

Il vaut au moins vingt mille euros. Si je te le donne maintenant, tu n’auras pas de droits a payer plus tard. Mets-le 4 l’abri dans un coin sir et comme ga d’ici quelques années, le tour est joué, c’est a toi. Personne n’y verra que du feu.
Oui mais je n’en veux pas.
Il plaira peut-étre 4 ta future femme.
Avant ga il faudrait déja que je me trouve une copine, tu ne crois pas?
C'est cher la vie 4 New York, tu sais.
J'y vais avec un trés bon boulot, comme je te l’ai déja dit. Je sais que ga te dépasse, mais je gagne extrémement bien ma vie.
Je sais. Et je n’approuve pas.
Que tu approuves ou pas, ¢a m’est égal. 68.
I don't want this.
It's worth at least twenty thousand. If you take it now, there won't be any taxes later. Just put it away somewhere very safe. Then in a few years, voila, it's yours. No one will know the difference.
I don't want it.
Maybe your future wife will like it.
I'd first need to find a girlfriend, don't you think?
New York can be very expensive, you know.
I have a good job. You know that. I know it’s hard for you to believe, but I make a lot of money.
I know. I don't approve.
I don't care if you approve. She forcefully hands him the bracelet.
Bon allez. Prends-le. 69.
Here. Take it. Paul holds the bracelet, finally, but looks at it without much care.
Il y a autre chose dont it faut qu’on discute. Cette histoire de trust dont a parlé Sylvia. L’argent, c’est ton domaine. De quoi il s'agit?

Pour ga il faudrait qu’on prenne rendez-vous avec un avocat, quelqu’un qui maitrise vraiment le sujet. Ca ne se régle pas comme ga et on n’est pas obligés de parler de droits de succession maintenant. Si on est en vacances c’est justement pour oublier tout ga.
C’est pourtant vité réglé. Tout ce que j’ai, c’est l’‘appartement de Paris. Je l’ai déja mis en vente, et j’ai l’intention de léguer ce que je vais en tirer au Conservatoire.
Ah bon? Tu leur en fais don? Et Jimmy, il le sait déja?

Mais, oui. Bien sir. Toi, tu n’as pas besoin de moi. Tu me l‘'as déja parfaitement fait comprendre. Jimmy s’est trés bien débrouillé, il a mis ce qu’il lui faut de cdté. Sylvia peut compter sur Ian. Je suis stire qu’il a gagné encore plus d’argent que toi.
There's something else we need to talk about. This incorporating idea of Sylvia's. Money is your business. What is she talking about?

I think we should just set up a meeting with a lawyer, someone who really understands the situation. These things are complicated. We don't need to talk inheritance taxes while we're here. It's a vacation from all of that.
Not much to talk about. All I have is the apartment in Paris. I've already put it on the market. I intend to donate the proceeds to the Conservatoire.
Really? You're giving it away? Does Jimmy know?

Yes. Of course. You don't need me. You've made that perfectly clear. And Jimmy's saved plenty from his own work. There's more than enough there. And Ian will take care of Sylvia. I'm sure he's made even more than you.

Sirement. Je ne suis pas en train de me plaindre, Maman. Je n’ai aucune envie de vivre a Paris. Si tu veux faire don de l’appartement, vas-y. Simplement... je suis surpris. Il vaut tant que ga de toute fagon?
J’'en demande trois millions. Tu connais le quartier.
A mon avis tu te trompes.

Ne me dis pas que je me trompe. Tu n’as pas a me rabaisser comme ga. Ca n’est vraiment pas nécessaire. Et ensuite le Conservatoire s'est engagé a créer une bourse Frangoise Cremont pour les apprentis comédiens.
Ah d’accord...

Je sais que c’est vaniteux de ma part. Mais c’est ga que je veux, et je prends mes dispostions en conséquence. J'ai besoin que tu t’assures qu’ils le feront bien. Tu peux me promettre de t’en occuper, Paul?
Qu’ils feront bien quoi?
Qu’ils créeront bel et bien cette bourse!
Non mais arréte, 1a! On dirait que tu parles d’une bande d’escrocs. 70.

I'm sure. I'm not complaining, Maman. I don't want to live in Paris anyway. It's fine for you to give the apartment away. I'm just... I'm surprised. Is the apartment really worth that much money anyway?
I'm asking three million. You know the neighborhood.
I think you're mistaken.
Don't tell me I'm mistaken. Don't put me down like that. It's not necessary. It's not. And the school has promised they would set up a Frangoise Cremont Scholarship for young actors.
Ah. I see.
It's vanity, I know. But I want it, and I'm planning for it now. I need you to make sure they do it. Can you promise me that, Paul?
They do what?
Set up the scholarship!
Oh, please. They're not crooks.
Quant au reste, il n’y a pas grand-chose. Je le donne au fur et a mesure. 71.

The rest, there's not much. I'm giving it away as I go. Paul looks at the bracelet again. This time, the light hi it’s precious stones, and it shines brighter: it seems to hold more value than just a few seconds before.
Tu as vu Ilene?
C’est qui Ilene?
Mon amie Ilene. Elle est arrivée.
Ilene. Celle dont tu parles tous le temps.
Oui. Mon amie chef-coiffeuse. Elle a énormement de talent. Et puis elle est maligne comme tout, et elle me fait rire. Je suis stire qu’elle te plairait.
Elle habite & New York... Frankie nods.
Et elle n’a pas de mec.
Ah ga, je n’en sais rien. Mais elle est trés jolie. Elle est beaucoup plus jeune que moi.
Et comme par hasard elle débarque a Sintra en méme temps que nous.
Have you seen Ilene yet?
Who's Ilene.
My friend Ilene. She's here.
Ilene. The one you always talk about.
Yes. My hair stylist friend. She's so talented. Smart, she makes me laugh. I am sure you'd really like her.
She lives in New York.
And she's single.
Ah, that-- I don't know. But she's very pretty. She's much younger than me, you know.
And she happens to be in Sintra at the same time that we are here.
Elle traville en Espagne. C’est juste a cdté.
C’était censé étre des vancances en famille!
Elle est sur le tournage du nouveau Star Wars. C’est énorme! Donc tu vois, quand je te dis qu’elle est douée... 72.
She's working in Spain, around the corner.
This was supposed to be a family vacation!

She's on the new Star Wars movie. It's a major job. Shows you how good she is. All of a sudden, the bracelet feels heavy on Paul’s hand. He’s clearly very upset, and he tosses the bracelet up an down.
C’est marrant. La plupart des méres trouvent que personne n’est jamais assez bien pour les fils.
Je ne sais pas de quelles méres tu parles. Pas la mienne en tout cas. Du moment qu’il était un homme et pas juif, elle était ravie. Ca lui était méme égal qu’il soit homo. They pause, angry.
Paul, toute ta vie je t’ai toujours donné tout ce que tu as voulu, et pourtant tu n’es jamais content de rien. Rien ne te suffit jamais. Aucune femme. Aucun homme. Aucune mére. Aucun pére.
Funny. For most mothers, there is never anyone good enough for their sons.
I don't know what mothers you are talking about. Not my mother. As long as he was a man and he wasn't a Jew, she was perfectly happy. She didn't even care if he was a homosexual.

Paul, I've given you everything you've ever wanted your whole life, and yet you are never satisfied with anything. Nothing is enough for you. No woman. No man. No mother. No father. In one quick gesture, Paul throws the bracelet away, far down the hill.
Paul?! Mais tu es malade??
Paul?! Are you crazy??  31 73. Paul turns around and walks away from his mom, furious. Frankie takes off, goes running down the hill, dropping t bouquet of flowers behind her.
Paul is still fuming, walking with firm, fast steps, when runs into Sylvia.
There you are.

I just came from talking with Frankie.
And?

The level of manipulation is beyond anything I can fully explain. And by the way, she’s selling the Paris apartment, so don’t get your hopes up. She’s getting all her ducks in a row, as the Americans say. You knew she would leave nothing to chance.
What do you mean she’s selling the apartment?

It’s already on the market, and she’s made up her mind. She's leaving everything she’s got to the Conservatoire, which is not much, it turns out, besides the apartment. The news stops Sylvia cold in her tracks. She leans on th ancient, moss covered rail wall that accompanies the road

She worked her whole life. She can do whatever she wants with her money. And what she wants is to be remembered. She’s setting up the Frangoise Cremont Scholarship Fund for poor and needy actresses. That’s what she wants. I’m sorry her death won’t help you leave your boring husband, but I quite like the idea. Sylvia picks up her pace, walking fast away from Paul.
Sylvia. Sylvia!

If you stumble upon a Bulgari bracelet, it’s mine.

Emeralds, rubies and diamonds. Ilene goes down on the ground and looks around her, and s does Frankie. They can’t find anything.  75. They’re both on all fours, now face to face, and they sta laughing.

I’m not.

My stupid son.
Paul?
It’s the only one I have. Help me up here. I’ve looked everywhere already. Ilene gets up, and extends her hand. Frankie holds it, an she gets up, she falls into Ilene’s arms.

It’s good to see you. Frankie’s face looks more pale than normal. Her eyes lose sight, her lips lose their color. She feels suddenly dizz
Frankie.

Help me. Ilene rushes to hold her friend, but as she does, Frankie starts to fall down.
Frankie!  33 76. Ilene still tries to hold her up, but once she notices it serious, and Frankie is actually falling, she lets her to ground, carefully, holding her head so it doesn’t hit anything.
Oh my God. Frankie! Frankie lies on the ground, as her eyes roll back, and th muscles in her body jerk rhythmically for a second. Ilene stands back, desperate, unsure of what to do.
Ian and Sylvia sit at a restaurant in the city of Sintra. He’s served a salad by the WAITER, while Sylvia picks on bread and butter at the table.

I'll have a glass of wine. Waiter! The Waiter comes back, while Sylvia is looking at the men

Regardless of what I feel, and of what I think you feel, we have a home and an amazing daughter, and... maybe it’s my personality, I don’t know... I didn’t grow up like you. All of you. I don’t have the same expectations maybe. I’d like to think that our life together, our family, is the most important thing.  77. Sylvia wasn’t expecting this. She takes a sip of Ian’s wh wine. IAN (CONT’D) Of course I can fantasize once ina while what my life would be like if I had made different choices. That’s normal. It’s human. But actually going through a divorce? It hasn't crossed my mind.
Never?
No.
Well, I can’t say the same. They sit in a silence for a moment.

So then you must know that there’s only one ‘ground’ for divorce under British law, which is that the marriage has irretrievably broken down. Five facts may constitute this ground: adultery, unreasonable behavior, two years separation, if both parties consent; five years separation, if only one party consents, and two years desertion. Ian pauses, and eats a small bite of his meal. IAN (CONT’D) I've been faithful to you, Sylvia. It would take a long, very expensive legal battle to try and prove unreasonable behavior on my part, which I think would be your only possible path.
I never thought about getting into a battle with you.
So I’m glad we’re having this conversation, because I wouldn't just let you go, Sylvia. You’d have to take me to a court of law, that’s what it would take.  78.
God, you did more research than I did.
Of course I did. I called a lawyer. What do you expect me to do? He made some calculations for me.
Calculations!

I like to be prepared. You must have made calculations, yourself, but this is what we came up with. In the unlikely event that you are granted a decree Absolute, since you don’t have a salary, your alimony would get you, according to our calculations, a one bedroom in Upper Edmonton, maybe a two bed/one bath in Lower Edmonton. The Waiter arrives with Sylvia's glass of white wine.
That’s where Maya’s kick boxing instructor lives.
Is she the Bolivian?
Yes.
Then, maybe. That would make sense. I hear Lower is very popular among South American immigrants. Sylvia takes a sip of her wine, and gets up.
I’m going to go.
You don’t want to go with me to pick up Maya?
No. I want to go see the Regaleira.  34 79.
You want to go see the Regaleira. I see. What is the Regaleira, may I ask?
It doesn’t matter.
No, that’s right. You’re right, Sylvia. It doesn’t matter. Sylvia turns around, and heads out. Ian, disappointed, pi up her glass full of wine.

“Trouve avant de chercher."” Ilene looks at her, not following.

I don’t know if it’s the mountain air, or these beautiful surroundings, I don’t know... but I realized today that love is all that matters. Not money. Not jobs, or movies. Or even companionship.
